story.text: <iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/27671347?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
We show how drag-and-drop between federated wiki pages creates a new model for sharing. A simple JSON model of the page makes this all straightforward.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/27673743?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>

We explore how a federated wiki's page elements get converted to HTML. The conversion happens on the client side. Coffeescript code uses the type of each story item to retrieve "emit" and "bind" functions. Emit creates the HTML DOM objects while bind connects them up to jQuery.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/28247053?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>

We show an Arduino micro controller collecting data from various sensors and publishing it as a federated wiki page. Squeezing wiki onto the smallest of machines shows us ever more powerful ways to program this new system.
See also Remote Sensing with Federated Wiki

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/28774310?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
We show more ways to see multiple pages at once where drag-and-drop works like columns in the finder. We also show file import through drag-and-drop from the finder.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/29540539?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
When we edit a remote page it becomes our own. We call this a fork and record it in the journal. Click the journal to bring the source up for side-by-side comparison.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/29540826?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
A visualization on one page can find data on another. Our prototype showed us this is a good way to work. Watch us visualize two datasets two different ways.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/29929074?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
We find inspiration in Science Magazine's interactive figures prepared for their special issue on population. We're using similar javascript libraries and hope to make publishing with them easy.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/30340726?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
Where is wiki from? Where might it go to? We asked and answered these questions in a 2005 Wikimania keynote. Our answers hold up. Some guide our work today.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/32051583?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>

Adam Solove has contributed side-scrolling and browser history integration logic. Bryan Donovan and Stephen Judkins have put together rspec and capybara tests. I promise to fix the bug I introduced generating favicons.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/32056225?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>

Russell Senior and Sven Dowideit have contributed to the Arduino and Node.js server implementations which stretch our understanding of federation. With so much of the logic on the client side, we can even make read-only sites with Apache.

We introduce the parts of a Federated Wiki page. The "story" is a collection of paragraphs and paragraph like items. The "journal" collects story edits. Should you take my page and edit it as yours, I can see what you've done and may decide to take your edits as my own.

<iframe style="-moz-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;box-shadow: 5px 8px 10px 5px #888;" src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/27671065?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0" width="400" height="250" frameborder="0"></iframe>
